questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the second most common malignancy in childhood?
questions.explanation: The second most common malignancy in childhood is a brain tumor. The most common malignancy in childhood is Leukemias. Brain tumors in childhood: • Most common solid tumor in children- Brain tumor • Most common site of a brain tumor in children- Infratentorium • Most common brain tumor in childhood- Pilocytic astrocytoma

Question 3: A mother brought her 10-month-old baby to the hospital with sudden onset vomiting. She has 
also been noticing an alarming increase in the head size of the baby. On examination, 
significant macrocephaly is seen. MRI reveals a supratentorial tumor. Which of the following 
tumors is the most likely cause of this child's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Choroid plexus carcinoma is a pediatric supratentorial tumor presenting with macrocephaly and 
focal neurologic deficits. Choroid plexus tumors are the most common CNS tumors in children aged less than 1 year. These 
tumors are intraventricular epithelial neoplasms arising from the choroid plexus. Children present with signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), whereas 
infants may present with macrocephaly and focal neurologic deficits. Medulloblastoma, pilocytic astrocytoma, and ependymoma, are all predominantly infratentorial 
tumors. The age-related differences in the primary location of the tumor are given below: Age

questions.question:
Question 4: 661 
Sold by @itachibot Sanam, a 7-year-old kid is suspected to have an ependymoma. Which of the following features 
on histopathology would favor this diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Perivascular rosettes will be seen on histopathological examination of ependymoma. Other 
features include ependymal rosettes and monomorphic nuclear morphology. Ependymomas are tumors derived from the ependymal lining of the ventricular system occurring 
predominantly in childhood. They are usually non-invasive, extending into the ventricular lumen 
and/or displacing normal structures, sometimes leading to significant obstructive hydrocephalus. 677 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A young child was evaluated for increased ICP. A brain tumor was found on an MRI scan. It 
was resected and sent for histopathological examination. The slide is shown below. This 
tumor is found most commonly in the  
.
questions.explanation:
The slide shows perivascular pseudorosettes and ependymal rosettes, characteristic of 
ependymoma. The most common site of ependymoma in children is the floor of the 4th ventricle. 
Monomorphic nuclear morphology can also be noted. Ependymomas are tumors derived from the ependymal lining of the ventricular system, occurring 
predominantly in childhood. These tumors are usually non-invasive, extending into the 
ventricular lumen and/or displacing normal structures, sometimes leading to significant 
obstructive hydrocephalus.

questions.question:
Question 6: A concerned mother brought her daughter to the clinic for evaluation of symptoms that have 
worsened in the last few weeks. The daughter frequently wakes up at night with severe 
headaches and vomiting. She has also been having some difficulty walking. On examination, 
ataxia and multiple cranial nerve palsies are noted. Imaging is suggestive of a brainstem 662 
Sold by @itachibot tumor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The MRI given shows a diffuse, infiltrating pontine lesion. Multiple cranial nerve dysfunctions, 
cerebellar signs, motor weakness, and features of raised intracranial pressure (ICP) are all 
strongly suggestive of a pontine glioma. These are not amenable for surgical resection. The standard approach is radiation therapy. The 
prognosis is very poor.

questions.question:
Question 7: On your neurology rotation, you come across Ashu, a 5-year-old child who presented with a 
6-month history of ataxia, headaches, and vomiting. He was admitted to the ward for further 
evaluation. MRI scan showed a brain tumor with a combination of solid and cystic 
components. Biopsy findings of the tumor are shown in the image. Which of the following is 
the most likely diagnosis? 663 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given slide shows condensed masses of glial filaments occurring in compact areas suggestive 
of Rosenthal fibers. The clinical features, MRI findings, and histopathology point towards a 
diagnosis of pilocytic astrocytoma. Pilocytic astrocytoma is a low-grade astrocytoma tumor. It is the most common type of 
astrocytoma in children. These are classically found in the cerebellum (infratentorial) and the 
optic pathway regions. There is usually a 3-6 month history of limb ataxia, secondary headaches, and vomiting. Mural 
nodule, a contrast medium enhancing nodule within the wall of a cystic mass is seen on MRI. The tumor has a low metastatic potential and is rarely invasive.

questions.question:
Question 9: You are a pathology resident who is looking at a slide, showing small round blue cells and 
Homer-Wright rosettes as shown below. The history you received from the pediatric surgery 
resident was that the specimen was resected from a 5-year-old child with ataxia. The tumor 
was present in the midline vermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 664 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and slide are suggestive of Medulloblastoma. Medulloblastoma is an embryonal CNS tumor, occurring predominantly in the cerebellar vermis 
that causes ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. It may cause obstructive hydrocephalus and 
often metastasizes extraneurally. Histopathology shows a tumor composed of small, round, blue cells and is characterized by 
Homer–Wright rosettes and an immunopositivity for synaptophysin. Standard treatment for medulloblastomas is surgical resection, with adjuvant craniospinal 
radiotherapy for those over 3 years of age and chemotherapy. Prognosis is strongly influenced by surgical resection, the presence of CSF metastases at the time 
of diagnosis, and the expression of the c-erbB-2 (HER2/neu) oncogene. Note: Small, round, blue-cell tumors are malignant neoplasms that have a characteristic 
appearance under the microscope. It consists of sheets of small round cells that stain blue on 
routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. Examples are: • Medulloblastoma • Neuroblastoma • Retinoblastoma • Ewing’s sarcoma • Rhabdomyosarcoma

questions.question:
Question 10: A child is brought to the emergency department by his teacher when he started having 
abnormal jerking movements during math class. The parents give a history of the child 
having similar episodes in the past. On the way to the CT room, the child had an episode of 
seizure and was stabilized with lorazepam. The imaging done is shown below. What is the 
most likely diagnosis? 665 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
679 
Sold by @itachibot Calcified cortical mass with a seizure is suggestive of oligodendroglioma. Oligodendrogliomas are uncommon tumors of childhood. These infiltrating tumors occur 
predominantly in the cerebral cortex and originate in white matter. Treatment involves surgical 
resection followed by involved field radiation therapy. The image below shows histology of oligodendroglioma showing characteristic fried egg 
appearance and chicken wire capillaries. Craniopharyngioma is associated with suprasellar calcification. Also, the child may often present 
with a history of endocrinological and visual complaints.

questions.question:
Question 11: An erythropoietin-secreting brain tumor is detected in a child. His father passed away one 
year back from end-stage renal cell carcinoma. Family history is significant for VHL 
mutation. On examination, a fiery red retina is seen. Which of the following is the most likely 
tumor present in this child?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a cerebellar hemangioblastoma. Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition. The major neurological 
features of VHL include cerebellar hemangioblastomas and retinal angiomas. Cerebellar hemangioblastomas are erythropoietin-secreting tumors, which can lead to 
polycythemia. It typically appears as a cystic cerebellar lesion with a vascular mural nodule on CT 
or MRI scan. Retinal angiomas are small masses of thin-walled capillaries, usually located in the peripheral 
retina that is fed by large and tortuous arterioles and venules appearing as a fiery red vascular 
mass. It can lead to retinal detachment and visual loss. 680 
Sold by @itachibot Associations of VHL syndrome include: • Cystic lesions of kidneys, pancreas, liver, and epididymis • Renal cell carcinoma (most common cause of death) • Pheochromocytoma • Cerebellar hemangioblastoma • Retinal angioma

questions.question:
Question 12: Akhil, a 15-year-old boy with sun-setting eyes, has a tumor in the pineal region as seen in the 
MRI. Parinaud syndrome is suspected. Which of the following findings will not be seen in this 
boy?

options.c: Convergence retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze

questions.explanation:
Parinaud’s syndrome refers to supranuclear vertical gaze disorder. Parinaud’s syndrome/dorsal midbrain syndrome is caused by damage to the posterior 
commissure. Classically, signs of hydrocephalus are seen due to aqueductal stenosis. Causes: • Pineal region or midbrain tumors (Most common cause) • Neurocysticercosis • Stroke • Multiple sclerosis Features include the following: • Loss of up-gaze (downward gaze is usually preserved) • Convergence–retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze • Downward ocular deviation- Setting-sun sign • Lid retraction- Collier's sign 681 
Sold by @itachibot • Pseudo-Argyll–Robertson pupil- Accommodative paresis ensues and pupils become mid-dilated 
and show light-near dissociation • Bilateral papilledema • Skew deviation • Pseudoabducens palsy

questions.question:
Question 13: An 8-year-old child is brought to the casualty after a minor accident that occurred when he 
failed to see a bike coming from sideways. His mother says he is a clumsy child, who 
sometimes knocks things over accidentally even at home. Visual field examination findings 
are given below. On imaging, an intracranial mass is seen. The resected specimen shows 
cholesterol-rich machinery-oil-like fluid. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Patients with adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma present with bitemporal hemianopia 
(image), and the cystic component of this tumor contains a cholesterol-rich, thick, 
brownish-yellow fluid that is comparable to "machine oil." Craniopharyngiomas develop from remnants of the Rathke pouch. Adamantinomatous variant of 
craniopharyngioma predominates in childhood. These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, 
and occur in the suprasellar region. Patients usually present with headache and visual field 
abnormalities. These children also have endocrinological abnormalities such as growth failure and 
delayed sexual maturation due to hypopituitarism (GH deficiency). These tumors are minimally invasive, adhere to the adjacent brain parenchyma, and engulf 
normal brain structures. CT may show calcifications associated with the solid and cystic 
components.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following is the most common extracranial solid tumor in the pediatric age 
group?
questions.explanation:
Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children and the most commonly 
diagnosed malignancy in infants. It is an embryonal cancer of the peripheral nervous system. The signs and symptoms depend on the location of the tumor and the extent of the disease. 
Neuroblastomas originating from the superior cervical ganglion can present with Horner 
syndrome. Metastatic disease can cause a variety of signs and symptoms, including the following • Fever • Irritability • Failure to thrive • Bone pain • Cytopenia • Bluish subcutaneous nodules • Orbital proptosis, and periorbital ecchymoses Rapid dancing eye movements (opsoclonus), rhythmic jerking of limbs/trunk (myoclonus), 
and ataxia are characteristic of the opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome (OMA). It is 682 
Sold by @itachibot a paraneoplastic syndrome of autoimmune origin with a strong association with neuroblastomas. Some neuroblastomas may undergo spontaneous regression, whereas some may be unresponsive

questions.question:
Question 15: A 5-year-old child presents with rapid dancing eye movements, rhythmic jerking of limbs and 
poor coordination. You suspect a paraneoplastic syndrome. Which of the following conditions 
should you look for in this child?
questions.explanation:
Rapid dancing eye movements (opsoclonus), rhythmic jerking of limbs/trunk (myoclonus) and 
ataxia is characteristic of opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome (OMA). It is a paraneoplastic 
syndrome of autoimmune origin with a strong association with neuroblastoma. All children with OMA should undergo investigations for neuroblastoma such as ultrasound 
followed by CT or MRI of chest and abdomen, bone scans and marrow biopsies. The definitive 
diagnosis of neuroblastoma is through biopsy which shows small round blue cells. Other small round blue cell tumours are medulloblastoma, retinoblastoma, Ewing’s sarcoma and 
rhabdomyosarcoma.

questions.question:
Question 16: In the ophthalmology OPD, you see a 3-year-old child with the following finding. There is no 
history of trauma. There is no significant family history. Which of the following is the most 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This image shows periorbital ecchymoses and proptosis suggestive of metastases of 
neuroblastoma (a sign of orbital bone involvement). Neuroblastomas may develop at any site in the sympathetic nervous system. Metastatic spread is 
common in children who are diagnosed after 1 year of age. It occurs via local invasion, 
hematogenous, or lymphatic routes. Metastatic disease can cause a variety of signs and symptoms, including the following: • Fever • Irritability • Failure to thrive • Bone pain 683 
Sold by @itachibot • Cytopenia • Bluish subcutaneous nodules • Orbital proptosis, and periorbital ecchymoses

questions.question:
Question 17: A 10-month-old infant is diagnosed with neuroblastoma. Which of the following factors is 
associated with a good prognosis?
questions.explanation:
Hyperdiploidy is associated with a good prognosis in neuroblastoma if the child is younger than 1 
year of age at diagnosis. Bad prognosis in neuroblastoma is seen in cases of: • Amplification of N-MYC • Loss of Heterozygosiy of 1p, 11 q ,14q • Gain of 17q • TrkB expression

questions.question:
Question 18: A 3-year-old boy presents with a 2-month history of an enlarging scalp lesion. There is no 
history of trauma to the head or scalp. The child is otherwise healthy and investigations are 
normal. X-ray of the head is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with the x-ray image showing a punched-out lytic lesion is suggestive of 
Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). LCH is a rare histiocytic disorder characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions that 
can infiltrate nearly every organ, most notably the skin (of the scalp), lungs, thymus, liver, spleen, 
bone marrow, or the central nervous system. LCH is so named because of its resemblance to the Langerhan’s cells, which are specialized 
dendritic cells found in the skin and mucosa.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 12-year-old child is brought with 4 small, purplish, rubbery lesions on his back and arms. 
On examination, you note inguinal freckling and nodules on the iris as shown below. Which 669 
Sold by @itachibot chromosome is involved in the syndrome described in this child?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 1. The NF1 gene on 
chromosome 17q11 is involved. It is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome. It is diagnosed when at least 2 of the following 7 criteria are met: • 6 or more cafe-au-lait macules • >5mm prepuberty • >15mm post-puberty • Skin-fold freckling- axillary and inguinal • 2 or more iris lisch nodules (image) • 2 or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma (purplish, rubbery lesions) 684 
Sold by @itachibot • Osseous lesions • Osseous dysplasia • Cortical thinning of long bones without a pseudoarthrosis • Low-grade astrocytomas like optic gliomas • 1st degree relative with diagnosed NF-1

questions.question:
Question 20: Vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and spinal cord ependymomas are the CNS 
manifestations of  
.
questions.explanation:
Vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and spinal cord ependymomas are the CNS 
manifestations of neurofibromatosis type 2 It is an autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs due to a mutation in the 
NF2 gene on chromosome 22q12. von Hippel–Lindau syndrome is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs 
due to a mutation in the VHL gene on chromosome 3p25-26. The CNS manifestation is usually a 
hemangioblastoma. Turcot syndrome is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs due to 
a mutation in the APC gene on chromosome 5q21. The CNS manifestation is a medulloblastoma.

questions.question: Question 22: What is the most common intraocular tumor diagnosed in the pediatric age group?
questions.explanation:
685 
Sold by @itachibot Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular tumor of the pediatric age group. It is an 
embryonal malignancy of the retina.

questions.question:
Question 23: James was brought by his mother for evaluation of a squint she noticed. On examination, the 
given finding was observed. Investigations revealed retinoblastoma with a germline RB1 gene 
mutation. The secondary malignancy most likely to develop in him is:
questions.explanation:
Children with germline RB1 mutations are at significant risk for the development of secondary 
malignancies, especially • Osteosarcoma (Most common) • Soft tissue sarcomas • Malignant melanoma The risk of secondary malignancies is further increased by the use of radiation therapy. A pineoblastoma occurring in a child with bilateral hereditary retinoblastoma is called 'trilateral 
retinoblastoma'. The image shows leukocoria, a white pupillary reflex. It may be seen in the following conditions: • Congenital cataract • Retinoblastoma • Retinopathy of prematurity (retrolental fibroplasia) • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous • Coats disease • Toxocara endophthalmitis

questions.question:
Question 24: 671 
Sold by @itachibot A 5-year-old boy presented with an abdominal mass. On examination, the mass is firm, 
smooth, non-tender, and does not cross the mid-line. The boy is also found to have moderate 
hypertension. Urinalysis reveals microscopic haematuria. Wilms tumor is suspected. This 
condition can be associated with all of the following except  
.
questions.explanation:
Polycystic kidneys are not associated with Wilm's tumor. Wilms tumor (WT), also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal 
tumor of childhood. Polycystic kidney disease can also present with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and hematuria. 
However, there will be multiple irregular cysts on ultrasound and is not associated with Wilms 
tumor.

questions.question:
Question 26: While posted in the pediatric oncology ward, you come across a case of metastatic triphasic 
nephroblastoma in a 4-year-old. What is the most common site for metastasis of this tumor?
questions.explanation:
The most common sites for metastases of nephroblastoma or Wilms tumor are the following: • Lungs (Most common) • Regional lymph nodes • Liver The triphasic components visualized on histopathology are- • Malignant small round (blue) cells (blastemal component). • Tubular structures/rosettes (epithelial component). • Loose pauci-cellular stroma with spindle cells (stromal component) 687 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 27: What is the most important determinant of prognosis in a child diagnosed with Wilm's 
tumor?

options.b: Loss of heterozygosity of chromosome 1 p

questions.explanation:
Histology is the most important determinant of prognosis in Wilm's Tumor. The absence of 
anaplasia is considered a favorable histological finding. Other prognostic factors for risk-adapted therapy include • Age • Stage • Tumor weight • Loss of heterozygosity at chromosomes 1p and 16q.

questions.question:
Question 28: A 5-year-old child comes with abdominal distension, a palpable mass, and gross hematuria. A 
biopsy of the mass shows the following picture. Which of the following paraneoplastic 
syndromes in not associated with this tumor?
questions.explanation:
The histopathological image shows the characteristic triphasic components of Wilm's tumor. Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy is not a paraneoplastic syndrome of Wilm's tumor. Several distinct paraneoplastic syndromes have been reported in Wilm's tumor. They are as 
follows: • Hypertension • Erythrocytosis/Polycythemia • Hypercalcemia • Cushing syndrome • Acquired von Willebrand disease 688 
Sold by @itachibot Bleeding may occur as a paraneoplastic syndrome in Wilm's tumor. It is due to acquired 
deficiency of von Willebrand factor or factor VII deficiency. The triphasic components visualized on histopathology are- • Malignant small round (blue) cells (blastemal component). • Tubular structures/rosettes (epithelial component). • Loose pauci-cellular stroma with spindle cells (stromal component)

questions.question:
Question 29: The most common soft tissue sarcoma in the pediatric age group is 
.
questions.explanation:
Rhabdomyosarcoma, a tumor of striated skeletal muscle, is the most common pediatric soft tissue 
sarcoma. The most common sites are- head and neck (25%) > genitourinary tract (24%) > extremities 
(19%) > orbit (9%).

questions.question:
Question 30: 673 
Sold by @itachibot A 4-year-old girl presents with the lesion shown in this picture. The diagnosis is 
.
questions.explanation:
The lesion seen in the picture is sarcoma botryoides Vaginal rhabdomyosarcoma may manifest as a grape-like mass of tumor tissue bulging through 
the vaginal orifice, known as sarcoma botryoides.

questions.question:
Question 31: The precursor lesion of Wilm's tumor is  
.
questions.explanation:
• Wilms tumor is derived from foci of incompletely differentiated/undifferentiated renal 
mesenchyme called nephrogenic rests. 689 
Sold by @itachibot • Nephrogenic rests usually regress or differentiate, but those that persist can become malignant. • Nephrogenic rests that persist abnormally in the kidneys into postnatal life are seen in 1% of 
children in the general population, but are seen in up to 90% of children who develop or have a 
family history of Wilms tumor.

questions.question:
Question 32: The term “trilateral retinoblastoma” refers to bilateral retinoblastoma +  
.
questions.explanation:
A pineoblastoma occurring in a child with bilateral hereditary retinoblastoma is called “trilateral 
retinoblastoma.” In hereditary retinoblastoma (having spontaneous germline RB1 mutation), second malignancies 
are a major concern. The most common second malignancy is osteosarcoma; other second 
neoplasms include rhabdomyosarcoma and melanoma.

questions.question:
Question 33: Tumor which may undergo spontaneous regression is  
.
questions.explanation:
Neuroblastoma is an embryonal cancer of the peripheral sympathetic nervous system with 
heterogeneous presentation and prognosis; some tumors may undergo spontaneous regression, 
whereas some may be unresponsive to therapy and run a very aggressive course.

questions.question: Question 34: Which of the following pediatric tumors is called a “triphasic" blastoma?
questions.explanation:
• The classic nephroblastoma, aka Wilms tumor, is a mixed tumor (more than one neoplastic cell 
type) derived from one germ-cell layer (examples: Wilms tumor and pleomorphic adenoma of 
salivary gland). • Histologically, it is made up of the classic "triphasic" combination (recapitulating stages of 
normal renal development) of • Stromal • Epithelial, and • Blast cells 690 
Sold by @itachibot Musculoskeletal Disorders
